speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. A public place.

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Enter LUCILIUS, with three Strangers

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Who, the Lord Timon? he is my very good friend, and

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: an honourable gentleman.

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: We know him for no less, though we are but strangers

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: to him. But I can tell you one thing, my lord, and

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: which I hear from common rumours: now Lord Timon's

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: happy hours are done and past, and his estate

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: shrinks from him.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Fie, no, do not believe it; he cannot want for money.

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: But believe you this, my lord, that, not long ago,

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: one of his men was with the Lord Lucullus to borrow

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: so many talents, nay, urged extremely for't and

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: showed what necessity belonged to't, and yet was denied.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: How!

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: I tell you, denied, my lord.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: What a strange case was that! now, before the gods,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: I am ashamed on't. Denied that honourable man!

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: there was very little honour showed in't. For my own

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: part, I must needs confess, I have received some

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: small kindnesses from him, as money, plate, jewels

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: and such-like trifles, nothing comparing to his;

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: yet, had he mistook him and sent to me, I should

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: ne'er have denied his occasion so many talents.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Enter SERVILIUS

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: See, by good hap, yonder's my lord;

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: I have sweat to see his honour. My honoured lord,--

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: To LUCIUS

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Servilius! you are kindly met, sir. Fare thee well:

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: commend me to thy honourable virtuous lord, my very

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: exquisite friend.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: May it please your honour, my lord hath sent--

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Ha! what has he sent? I am so much endeared to

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: that lord; he's ever sending: how shall I thank

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: him, thinkest thou? And what has he sent now?

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: Has only sent his present occasion now, my lord;

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: requesting your lordship to supply his instant use

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: with so many talents.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: I know his lordship is but merry with me;

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: He cannot want fifty five hundred talents.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: But in the mean time he wants less, my lord.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: If his occasion were not virtuous,

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: I should not urge it half so faithfully.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Dost thou speak seriously, Servilius?

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: Upon my soul,'tis true, sir.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: What a wicked beast was I to disfurnish myself

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: against such a good time, when I might ha' shown

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: myself honourable! how unluckily it happened, that I

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: should purchase the day before for a little part,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: and undo a great deal of honoured! Servilius, now,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: before the gods, I am not able to do,--the more

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: beast, I say:--I was sending to use Lord Timon

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: myself, these gentlemen can witness! but I would

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: not, for the wealth of Athens, I had done't now.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Commend me bountifully to his good lordship; and I

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: hope his honour will conceive the fairest of me,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: because I have no power to be kind: and tell him

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: this from me, I count it one of my greatest

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: afflictions, say, that I cannot pleasure such an

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: honourable gentleman. Good Servilius, will you

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: befriend me so far, as to use mine own words to him?

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: Yes, sir, I shall.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: I'll look you out a good turn, Servilius.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Exit SERVILIUS

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: True as you said, Timon is shrunk indeed;

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: And he that's once denied will hardly speed.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Do you observe this, Hostilius?

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: Ay, too well.

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Why, this is the world's soul; and just of the

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: same piece

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Is every flatterer's spirit. Who can call him

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: His friend that dips in the same dish? for, in

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: My knowing, Timon has been this lord's father,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: And kept his credit with his purse,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Supported his estate; nay, Timon's money

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Has paid his men their wages: he ne'er drinks,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: But Timon's silver treads upon his lip;

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: And yet--O, see the monstrousness of man

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: When he looks out in an ungrateful shape!--

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: He does deny him, in respect of his,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: What charitable men afford to beggars.

speaker: Third Stranger
text_entry: Religion groans at it.

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: For mine own part,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: I never tasted Timon in my life,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Nor came any of his bounties over me,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: To mark me for his friend; yet, I protest,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: For his right noble mind, illustrious virtue

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: And honourable carriage,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Had his necessity made use of me,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: I would have put my wealth into donation,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: And the best half should have return'd to him,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: So much I love his heart: but, I perceive,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Men must learn now with pity to dispense;

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: For policy sits above conscience.

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Exeunt
